item.title: Word of the Day: sporadic
item.description: This word has appeared in 282 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Trump and India Call Off Their Trade War, but the Terms of Peace Are Murky
item.description: Officials and business leaders sighed with relief at lower tariffs, as they wait to see what the rest of it means.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India visited the White House last February, before bilateral relations between the country decayed.

item.title: The Long Game Behind Xi Jinping’s P.L.A. Purge
item.description: His sweeping military shake-up may look like weakness but it’s clearing the way for a more dangerous force under his full control.
item.dc:creator: John Garnaut

item.title: Immigration Officers in Minneapolis to be Equipped With Body Cameras
item.description: The homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, ordered all immigration officers in Minneapolis to wear body cameras. The move comes after fatal shootings where federal accounts conflicted with local officials and witness videos.
item.dc:creator: Jiawei Wang

media:content.media:description: Federal agents and a protester in a confrontation in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: China’s Disappearing Generals
item.description: For three years, Xi Jinping has been cleaning out the Chinese military elite, bringing high-level dismissals and disappearances to nearly every arm of the military.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, Agnes Chang and Chris Buckley

item.title: Lo mejor y lo peor de los Grammy 2026
item.description: Addison Rae explotó la energía pop de la década de 2000, Justin Bieber se quitó la ropa y Bad Bunny se quedó sin habla en la edición 68 de los premios anuales.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles, Lindsay Zoladz and Joe Coscarelli

media:content.media:description: Sabrina Carpenter performing “Manchild” early in the ceremony.

item.title: Quote of the Day: To Feel Fulfilled, Star Must Finish With Tank Empty
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 3, 2026.

item.title: Editors’ Note: Feb. 3, 2026
item.description: The following Editors’ Note and corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 3, 2026.

item.title: Pirro Threatens Jail Time for Lawful Gun Owners Who Travel to D.C. With Firearms
item.description: The remarks by Jeannine Pirro, the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, prompted swift pushback from the Republican Party’s pro-Second Amendment wing.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jeanine Pirro, the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, in November.

item.title: Trump Administration Sued Over Cutting Off Funds for $16 Billion Tunnel
item.description: The Gateway Development Commission said that if the federal government continued to withhold funding for a rail link under the Hudson River, it would have to stop construction this week.
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGeehan

item.title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Minnesota, Homicides, 'Heated Rivalry'
item.description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Engle

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 3, 2026
item.description: Nate Cardin’s puzzle invites you to listen closely.
item.dc:creator: Juliana Pache

media:content.media:description: Coffee and a puzzle: the perfect pair.

item.title: From ‘Hamilton’ to Issa Rae to Philip Glass: Here’s a List of Kennedy Center Cancellations
item.description: More than two dozen musicians, dancers, theater companies and other creative groups have pulled out of performing at the Kennedy Center since President Trump returned to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The composer Philip Glass in 2015.

item.title: Read the Decision
item.description: A federal judge temporarily blocked the Trump administration from ending Temporary Protected Status for more than 350,000 Haitians in the United States.

item.title: Trump Says He’s Only Renovating the Kennedy Center
item.description: Even though President Trump held a movie premiere for his wife’s new film there last week, he said the state of the building was “actually sort of dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh, Julia Jacobs and Luke Broadwater
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The announcement raised questions about whether President Trump has the power to unilaterally shut down and renovate the Kennedy Center.

item.title: Woman’s Dismembered Body Is Found in a Brooklyn Basement, Officials Say
item.description: The police are investigating the death of Michelle Montgomery, whose remains were found in a public housing building in the Williamsburg neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan and Sean Piccoli
item.category: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The remains of Michelle Montgomery, 39, were found in the basement of a building in the Borinquen Public Houses complex on Bushwick Avenue on Sunday morning, the police said.

item.title: H.H.S. to Expand Faith-Based Addiction Programs for Homeless
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said addiction is a “spiritual disease” that calls out for the involvement of religious organizations.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Bujalski for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, said the federal government would open funding opportunities to faith-based organizations that hold to evidence-based standards.

item.title: N.F.L. Says It Will Look Into Steve Tisch’s Ties to Epstein
item.description: Recently released emails reveal that Jeffrey Epstein sought to connect Mr. Tisch, whose family is a part-owner of the New York Giants, with multiple women.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas

media:content.media:description: Steve Tisch said in a statement that he’d had a “brief association” with Jeffrey Epstein that he deeply regretted.

item.title: DOJ Failed to Address Press Law in Application to Search Washington Post Reporter’s Home
item.description: The Justice Department did not address a 1980 law that generally bars warrants for reporting material when it sought to seize a Washington Post reporter’s devices, an unsealed filing shows.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press

media:content.media:description: First Amendment scholars say a search of a Washington Post reporter’s home appears to be unprecedented.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Trump Administration From Ending TPS for Haitians
item.description: The ruling pauses the Trump administration’s plan to end a program that has allowed more than 350,000 people from Haiti to remain in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan

media:content.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Haitian family received help obtaining passports and documents at the St. Vincent de Paul center in Springfield, Ohio, last month.

item.title: Epstein Victims Ask Judge to Shut D.O.J. Website After Names Disclosed
item.description: A judge will hold a hearing on Wednesday after attorneys for victims in the Epstein case said the recent batch of documents released by the government included their names.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser

media:content.media:description: Lawyers for victims in the Jeffrey Epstein case say the Department of Justice failed thousands of times to properly redact the names of their clients in the latest release of documents.

item.title: Why Texas Is the Wildest Story in U.S. Politics Right Now
item.description: First came a remarkable State Senate upset. Next up: two high-octane U.S. Senate primaries.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein

media:content.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Taylor Rehmet, a Democrat, won an upset victory in a Texas State Senate special election last weekend.

item.title: First Vehicles Cross Reopened Gaza Border
item.description: The Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt reopened Monday after having been largely closed since May 2024. It allowed some Gazans who had fled during the war to return. Sick and wounded people waiting for treatment abroad were able to cross into Egypt.

item.title: Waymo Raises $16 Billion to Fuel Global Ambitions
item.description: The self-driving car company, an arm of Google’s parent company, is rapidly expanding its service beyond a handful of cities.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha

media:content.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Waymo, Alphabet’s driverless car outfit, said it was now valued at $126 billion.

item.title: Immigration Officers in Minneapolis Will Wear Body Cameras, Noem Says
item.description: The change comes as the federal government has provided accounts of fatal shootings that have sometimes conflicted with local officials and witness videos.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo

media:content.media:description: Federal agents and a protester in a confrontation in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Maryland Moves to Give Democrats Extra House Seat, but Big Hurdles Remain
item.description: The state’s House of Delegates passed a new map that would be likely to eliminate Maryland’s lone remaining Republican seat in the U.S. House, but the State Senate may well block the measure.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Campbell Robertson

media:content.media:credit: Jonathan Newton for The Washington Post, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Democratic-led push to redraw Maryland’s congressional maps is part of a nationwide effort by Democrats to keep pace in a redistricting arms race set off by Republicans in Texas last summer.

item.title: El gobierno de EE. UU. publicó docenas de fotos con desnudos en los archivos Epstein
item.description: Las fotos, que mostraban a mujeres jóvenes o posiblemente adolescentes con la cara visible, fueron retiradas en su mayor parte después de que The New York Times empezara a notificarlo al Departamento de Justicia.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Julie Tate

media:content.media:description: Una foto sin fecha de Jeffrey Epstein publicada por el Departamento de Justicia.

item.title: Brad Karp Says He Regrets Interactions with Epstein
item.description: Newly released emails between Mr. Karp, the chairman of Paul Weiss, and Jeffrey Epstein reveal a number of social interactions between them.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Matthew Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Carly Zavala for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Brad Karp, above, became acquainted with Jeffrey Epstein largely through his legal work for Leon Black, a co-founder of Apollo Global Management.

item.title: Elon Musk fusiona SpaceX con su empresa de IA
item.description: El acuerdo entremezcla aún más las empresas de Musk y crea la empresa privada con mayor valoración del planeta.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Kate Conger, Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland

media:content.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Instalaciones de cohetes de SpaceX en Boca Chica, Texas.

item.title: Third Candidate Enters Heated Race for Open House Seat
item.description: Julie Won, a New York City councilwoman, will face two other Democrats, one backed by the departing incumbent, Nydia Velázquez, and the other by Mayor Zohran Mamdani.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

media:content.media:credit: Adam Gray for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Julie Won, a New York City councilwoman, immigrated to New York City from South Korea at the age of 8.

item.title: Trump Presses House G.O.P. to Back Deal to Reopen Government
item.description: Some hard-line House Republicans have balked at the deal Senate Democrats struck with President Trump to fund the government, complicating its path to enactment.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Catie Edmondson

media:content.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson will be able to afford just one defection on any party-line vote if all members are present.

item.title: Woodie King Jr., Impresario of Black Theater, Dies at 88
item.description: His New Federal Theater in New York provided a rare stage for Black playwrights and emerging actors, among them Denzel Washington, Phylicia Rashad and Chadwick Boseman.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf (Play)

media:content.media:credit: Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Woodie King Jr. in 2004 in front of the New Federal Theater in the Henry Street Playhouse building on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

item.title: ICE amplía el poder de sus agentes para arrestar a personas sin orden judicial
item.description: Un memo interno cambió el criterio que evaluaba si una persona estaba en riesgo de no presentarse a una audiencia judicial. Ahora se enfoca en evaluar si una persona está en riesgo de abandonar el lugar de los hechos.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz and Charlie Savage

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Agentes federales intentaron allanar una vivienda en Mineápolis a principios de esta semana.

item.title: Maps: Earthquakes Shake the San Francisco Bay Area
item.description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
item.dc:creator: William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe, Joey K. Lee and Bea Malsky

item.title: Justice Dept. Sidelines Ed Martin as Chief of Weaponization Group
item.description: The move represents a consolidation of the authority of the deputy attorney general, Todd Blanche, in bringing Mr. Martin’s operation inside his office.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer

media:content.media:description: Ed Martin, known by the self-bestowed moniker “Eagle Ed,” will retain his title as the Justice Department’s pardon attorney.

item.title: U.S. Military Tells Alaska and N.C. Troops to Stand Down on Possible Minnesota Deployment
item.description: More than 1,500 active-duty troops had been on standby to deploy to Minnesota, but were quietly taken off heightened alert over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Thousands marched in streets of Minneapolis on Friday to protest the federal immigration crackdown. Over the weekend, Northern Command quietly ordered the active-duty troops on standby to stand down.

item.title: Dan Bongino, Former Deputy F.B.I. Director, Returns to Podcasting
item.description: Mr. Bongino, who spent nine months at the agency, spoke freely about the Epstein files and more as he returned to the land of “sound bites.”
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson

media:content.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Dan Bongino attending the Memorial Service for Charlie Kirk in 2025. He resigned from the F.B.I. last month.

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Have Time to Think,’ Says Sergeant Who Threw Cooler at Man
item.description: Erik Duran, an N.Y.P.D. sergeant, said he was trying to save lives when he struck Eric Duprey with a cooler. The sergeant took the unusual step of testifying at his own manslaughter trial.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.category: Duran, Erik R (New York, NY, Police Officer)

media:content.media:credit: David Dee Delgado for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Sgt. Erik Duran is charged in the death of Eric Duprey, a Bronx man, in 2023. He took the stand in his own defense at his bench trial.

item.title: Trump Talked to Agents Investigating Election Claims
item.description: Also, the Supreme Court secretly made itself even more secretive. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Angel Restoration Resembles Italy’s Prime Minister
item.description: The face of an angel in a restored painting inside a chapel in Italy has many questioning its striking resemblance to Italy’s prime minister, Giorgia Meloni.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

media:content.media:description: A restored angel fresco with a figure resembling Giorgia Meloni in the Basilica of San Lorenzo in Lucina, in Rome.

item.title: Trump, in an Escalation, Calls for Republicans to ‘Nationalize’ Elections
item.description: The comments, made on a conservative podcast, follow a string of moves from his administration to try to exert more control over American elections.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti

media:content.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump has long been fixated on the false claim that voter fraud is rampant in the United States.

item.title: Trump Is Said to Have Dropped Demand for Cash From Harvard
item.description: Hours after The Times reported that President Trump had lowered the bar for a deal, he denied backtracking and made new threats against Harvard.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Michael S. Schmidt and Alan Blinder

media:content.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Harvard has faced internal pressure for months from faculty, students and alumni who view President Trump as an authoritarian and any deal as an act of capitulation.

item.title: Brendan Banfield Found Guilty in Virginia Double Murder Trial
item.description: Prosecutors said Brendan Banfield carried out an elaborate scheme using a fetish website in 2023 to kill his wife and another man.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin, JoAnna Daemmrich and Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:description: Brendan Banfield in court during his double murder trial in Fairfax, Va., last month.

item.title: Peter Attia, CBS News Contributor, ‘Ashamed’ After Epstein Files Made Public
item.description: The longevity influencer said he “never witnessed illegal behavior” but would not defend his crude remarks about women and comments on Jeffrey Epstein’s “outrageous” life.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: Elon Musk Merges SpaceX With His A.I. Start-Up xAI
item.description: The deal further intermingles Mr. Musk’s companies and creates the most valuable private company on earth.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Kate Conger, Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland

media:content.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: SpaceX’s rocket facility in Boca Chica, Texas.

item.title: Some Federal Workers Furloughed in Partial Government Shutdown
item.description: Some of the affected agencies announced sweeping furloughs, while others tapped reserve funds to get through what they expected to be a short shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media:content.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Much of the federal government closed over the weekend because of a lapse of funding for major agencies.

item.title: N.I.H. Worker Who Criticized Trump Seeks Whistle-Blower Protection
item.description: Jenna Norton, a National Institutes of Health employee, has been an outspoken critic of the administration’s research cuts and has been on paid leave.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
United States Office of Special Counsel

media:content.media:description: Jenna Norton last spring organized The Bethesda Declaration, a public letter that denounced what its authors viewed as the administration’s dismantling of the federal biomedical research apparatus.

item.title: John Forté, Who Forged a Hip-Hop Redemption Tale, Dies at 50
item.description: He seemed destined for a glittering career, working with the Fugees and solo, and then landed in prison. After a presidential pardon, he clawed his way back.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

media:content.media:description: John Forté in 2010. His rise in the music industry was swift, but his fall came just as quickly, when he was convicted of acting as a middleman in a scheme to transport $1.4 million worth of liquid cocaine.

item.title: How a Conservative Texas District Rejected the Politics of Division
item.description: Many Americans are growing both exhausted and frightened by Trump’s scorched-earth, hyperpartisan, fire-ready-aim approach to the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times

item.title: The Campaign Behind Trump’s Nigeria Strikes
item.description: A yearslong effort to convince the Trump administration that Christians are persecuted in the West African nation has shifted U.S. policy.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Taibat Ajiboye for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A resident of Jabo, Nigeria, with debris he said he found after a missile attack on Dec. 25 there.
